headline: German Potato Pancakes
description: These German potato pancakes are made with shredded potatoes and onion. They make a tasty side and a great savory alternative to regular pancakes.

video.description: See how to make real German-style potato pancakes.
video.name: German Potato Pancakes

name: German Potato Pancakes

recipeInstructions.text: Beat eggs, flour, baking powder, salt, and pepper together in a large bowl; stir in potatoes and onion.

Heat oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Drop heaping tablespoonfuls of potato mixture into hot oil in batches. Press to flatten. Cook until browned and crisp, about 3 minutes on each side. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate to drain. Repeat with remaining potato mixture.

review.reviewBody: Taste just like my mom's!

This is an easy recipe for a fast meal...The only change is I used 8 small Yukon gold, sprinkle of paprika, 1 tsp of salt, and added some bacon bits to the mixture...They were yummy!...I did take the advice of soaking the shreds in ice water until ready to mix.
I think it deserves a 5 star. It might be german but I am not and my family loves them.
Very delicious. I add a bit more salt and fresh parsley. So good

This is pretty close to my own recipe. My Late Mother regularly cooked this, and other German dishes that she learned from her German grandmother. I used chopped green onions and Idahoan dehydrated hash browns this time, and they came out good. These are great with Schnitzel and applesauce.

These pancakes are delicious and a welcome change on potatoes served another way! I have made these pancakes for years and I have learned a trick with discolouration of potatoes. I keep the shredded potatoes in cold water with lemon juice until I have done all the potatoes. Then drain all the water and carry on with recipe.

Sorry, but you left out a very important step - the grated potato needs to have all/most of the water squeezed out of it. Best done using muslin or good clean cotton teatowel. Put the mixture in the middle, pick up the corners and keep turning the underhanging ball until no more water drips out. Also, add some garlic for a bit of extra zing.
Flavorful and easy to make. Excellent for any meal . Leftovers heat well in oven.
Crispy out side, creamy inside, seasoning just right. Best compliment is that they taste just like my grandmother's
These were easy to make and tasted good!
Well see how they taste

These were fabulous. I don’t normally use recipes that require frying in oil, but I wanted German Potato Pancakes. I had never made them before but found myself craving them. Now that I made these, I know why. They were so good. Changes/ Lesson’s learned: These ended up quicker to make then I thought. I used a food processor to shred the potatoes and finely chop the onion. I learned you must have oil on the bottom of your fry pan or they do not fry well( they burn rather than become crispy and golden brown). I added some scallions for color and ate them with regular applesauce and some sour cream. Yum.
Very good.
I put raw potato in microwave 2 minutes turn 2 more minutes before I grate them
They turned out pretty good.
Love it! So easy, fast and delicious
They aren't exactly on my diet, but they were very good. I think I may try making them in the air fryer using parchment paper.
It turned out perfect and tasted great

Very good. Will double the onion and black pepper next time, personal preference. Shredded the potatoes one at a time and quickly submerged in ice water. Drained and placed in the center of a clean kitchen towel then out on the deck for a slingshot style spin until no more water coming out.

Did not change any ingredients as stated in recipe. Only thing I did different was left potatoes in water while preparing other food items to prevent discoloration. Used food process to mince up onion as kids like smaller bits. None were left!
Closest recipe to what my mother (a German immigrant) used to make. Wife likes them with applesauce I prefer sourcream.
I made them today for breakfast also served with a slice of Canadian bacon and it was awesome

My son picked these for a school project. We shredded the potatoes by hand on a box grater and put the potatoes in ice water to keep from oxidizing and got some of the starch out. We also grated the onion on the box grater to get them the same size and consistency as the potatoes for cooking. We drained the potatoes in a colander and dried them well then followed the recipe. I added a bit more salt and pepper, but otherwise the same. These turned out delicious- I am a huge fan of potato pancakes and these were crispy, had fabulous flavor and my son was over the moon. Served with applesauce, sour cream and chives. YUM! Will definitely be put in the family rotation.
No changes they were perfect
Excellent! I remember my dad cooking these for Christmas morning and they tasted as I remembered.
This was an easy recipe and super delicious.
wow.... 6 shredded potatoes made enough to feed an army. they we're tasty tho

Awesome! Could handle a bit extra salt in the recipe. And since only two of us will be halfing the recipe next time also. Served with Pear Butter and Pork — wow!
Make sure oil and pan are super hot so that the potatoes start sizzling immediately upon hitting the pan. It’s easier not to overload the pan with pancakes... they cooked better that way. Cheers!
Its easy to make and its really good but i recommend squeezing the potato before you put it in the mixture
perfect you just need about a quarter inch of oil in the pan at a time and they crisp up perfectly remember ring out the water very well

So good I’ve made them twice this week! I used the frozen shredded potatoes that I defrosted before hand. Afterwards I added sour cream and scallions. They were delicious, super crunchy outside but that soft mashed potato texture on the inside. They taste just like my favorite german restaurant’s potato pancakes in NY

My dinner guest loved it, they ate everything and wanted more, I had to tell them they ate it all...That made me Smile
As for changes, I did make one I added a slice of Havarti cheese to each one served with spicey Sausage and Red Cabbage Slaw
I would just add 1 clove of garlic to the original recipe, other than that - DELISH!
I added some fresh dill to season. This is a very good base recipe. My advice is to keep squeezing as much moisture as you can from the potatoes.

This recipe was fantastic! My dad wanted me to make something like what he used to eat when he lived in NY. So I tried this recipe. My mistake was to keep them warm @220 in the oven COVERED so they were not crispy. Next time will keep warm UNCOVERED. But it’s definitely a recipe I’ll make again and again!
Really good and easy recipe.
Very good. I soaked the shredded potatoes in ice water for about 1 hr. Drain them very well and pat dry with towels before mixing.
My husband wanted to try making these so I pulled up the recipe for him. I adjusted the recipe for 3. They were great and held together really well. Make sure your oil is good and hot for crisping.
This recipe was a complete failure. Pancakes took too long to brown, would not hold together, tasted like oil...yuck

I made this tonight with no changes to the recipe except that I did not squeeze out the potatoes. My husband and I both enjoyed the potato pancakes. I will keep this recipe. The recipe was correct when it said if the potatoes turn pink after you shred them they do become white again when you cook them.
Doubled the recipe and stringed the potato's in the processor came out great. Should have tripled
I did not change anything, as in any recipe I make, nor would I change it. I will absolutely make it again.
Amazing a must try! to avoid oxidation just put all the ingredients together and then add the shredded potatoes. Thank you for sharing.
This recipe takes me back to childhood. It’s wonderful! Thank you!
I used 4 eggs, mainly to hold the pancakes together better, and served them baked salmon. I am sure this will become a popular meal at our restaurant.
Simple and delicious. My only problem? No sour cream in the fridge!

So delicious! We don't own a food processor so had to grate it the old-fashioned way, (which did take quite a bit longer,) but they turned out perfect. Another time saving tip: On a busy morning/day, just prep the ingredients and put the bowl in the fridge. Once you're home, just give it a stir, heat up the oil, and... German Potato Pancakes, anyone?

These were great. I made so much I put some aside and mixed red bell pepper and garlic jalapeno seasoning. Those were FANTASTIC. I used 4 large potatoes and was able to put 8 pancakes in the fridge and warmed them up the next day on an ungreased cookie sheet at 325.
These are very yummy!

A perfect basic recipe for traditional potato pancakes. My great-aunt made them with ham and green onion, so I did that here and they were wonderful. I recommend experimenting with different meats,onions, and potatoes just for fun!
This was my first time cooking this and it turned out really well. We will make these again.
I made this recipe as written. It was easy to put together and made a delicious side dish for our bratwurst dinner. Thanks for sharing.
They were great. So easy to make with Yukon Gold’s right out of the garden. I didn’t change the recipe at all.

To this recipe I add a spoon full of oats to soak up some liquid. Also nutmeg and black pepper. We usually eat applesauce and/or salade with it. The trick it to grate the potatoes just before you are ready to cook.
Its really good! I would like to make it again.
These were really great. They tasted like a good hashbrown. The next morning we turned the leftovers into hash with bell peppers and eggs. We will be making this again one day!!

What a great recipe! I used two large Idaho potatoes, shredded and then wrung dry - almost too dry! So I added another egg and a teaspoon more flour, and they were just right. I also added dried Parsley and Chives (as that is what I had), additional salt sprinkled on as eaten, and they were delicious topped with sour cream and applesauce. Thank you for a great recipe!
I made them with frozen hash brown potatoes. Not bad at all. I should have got the oil hotter on the 1st batch but the second batch were brown perfectly.
I made this as written with the exception of cutting the recipe in half. Delicious!! Brought me back to when my mom used to make them. I will definitely make these again.
My Mom tought me how to make these exact ones when I was very young. But this German meal only goes with split pee soup!

We loved these! I’ve always wanted a good fried potato or hash brown recipe but had not found it. Now I have a “keeper” recipe! I added a little more salt and onion, plus a tablespoon of dried parsley. I used my fingers to pick up the potato mixture and drop it in the 12” iron skillet, then just pushed each clump down gently. I didn’t really flatten them. They were wonderfully crispy on the outside and potato-y soft on the inside. I had to add a little more oil a couple of times.
Added a little more salt! Just like my German Grandpa's ! Delicious!

I did not change this recipe at all and it was delicious! We had a bunch left over (family of four). I put them in the fridge and heated them up in a skillet the next morning to eat with our eggs. Yum.

Followed the recipe, except halved it as I cooked for one. As good as any potato pancakes as I have had. I did sift the flour and beat egg separately before adding to the dry ingredients. Used box grater to shread the potatoes and a mandolin to cut the onions quickly. I noted some asked about the potatoes turning brown. My suggestion is to have all ingredients prepped before peeling the potatoes, including having the egg mixture ready to receive the potatoes and onions. I highly recommend using cheesecloth to squeeze water from the potatoes. Enjoy, I did!

They were absolutely wonderful! I put in a whole onion and dropped them by 1/4 cups full. The whole family loved them. We will be having this breakfast quite often because it is delicious, easy to make and economical! We served them with sour cream and applesauce and had poached eggs for a complete breakfast!

This is an easy and delicious recipe. I used a food processor to finely shred the potatoes, one by one. As each potato was finished shredding, I immediately dropped them into a salad spinner filled with very cold water. When all the shredded potatoes were in the water I drained them, rinsed them twice more with fresh cold water, then spun them twice, squeezed handfuls of the potatoes draining as much of the remaining moisture, and dropped them into the egg and flour mixture. Following the remaining directions, I hand formed small pancakes, frying them 3 minutes in medium hot vegetable oil, which resulted in good crisp browning, and fluffy delicious pancakes with a hint of onion. Applesauce is a great accompaniment! Enjoy!
Delicious!

Reading some of the negative reviews, I feel that it's helpful to share what makes this recipe great and what can go wrong. There are no bad potatoes only bad potato preparation.
Using 6 medium potatoes is not a standard measurement so some of this is just going to come down to experience with the ingredients. If your potatoes are a little wet add more flour, I added 1 & 1/2 tablespoons more, with just a pinch of baking soda extra.
 Seasonings are really individual and these pancakes are often served with sausages or other foods so I don't feel that this is any fault at all in the recipe. Some side dishes are ment to be served like this to balance out other heavly seasoned foods. If you are making potato pancakes the star of the show then season them!
 For myself I added garlic salt, parsley and peprika. when frying this I liberally added butter and bacon fat ( cause a I had some on hand) and it turned out great. 
I served it with sour cream and ketchup but it can be sweet or savory. One other note is that leaving the peel on adds to the flavor and I mix my potatoes up. I like having russet, red and Yukon gold all together and this recipe benefits from the slightly varied tastes of the different potatoes mingled together.

I followed the directions; even taking the suggestions of the reviews with 5 stars. Not sure what I did wrong, but these fell apart when I was frying them. I agree they might be used for home fries, but not for potato pancakes.

I followed the directions; even taking the suggestions of the reviews with 5 stars. Not sure what I did wrong, but these fell apart when I was frying them. I agree they might be used for home fries, but not for potato pancakes.
This is a recipe my Mom never wrote down because it was a staple in our house. I have gotten close but not exactly till now.

For those who find this kinda bland make sure you added enough onion. When cakes are done top with applesauce
and/or maple syrup.

Very easy to make. Used my grater attachment on my kitchen aid, very fast to prep. Held grated potatoes in ice water then squeezed dry with paper towels. Used gluten free flour. They came out crispy & delicious! Added garlic & onion powder & salt. Served with apple sauce yum! Will make again
I would leave the onions undrained compensate with flour. That’s the true German Polish old country recipe

Brings back memories of the Christmas markets in Germany! It takes practice and a little finesse to get them perfect, but the recipe is great. Squeeze those potatoes out well with cheesecloth! I kept adding oil since my non stick pan makes a funny looking crust. Nothing like homemade chunky applesauce to go with it! Mmmm.
Spiced it up a chili powder and seasonal, kids loved them.

I make these often. Always a hit! A families favourite! One reviewer commented that these were bland...Don't be afraid to add more flavour. Add a bit of garlic powder or fresh garlic and the green of three green onions. I do and they always turn out. Our favourite topping is sour cream and salsa. Great with bacon or sausage. If you are a potato fan like me, you will love these tasty tater patties.

These potato pancakes are delicious! I cut the recipe in half as it was only myself and wife having dinner, I made my usual tweeks to the recipe measurements based on our taste , oh and I just added about a teaspoon of granulated garlic powder because we love garlic....lol. We had these as a side with with “Oktoberfest chicken and red cabbage “ another Allrecipes recipe posted by HerbanSpoons which happens to be FANTASTIC!
Excellent! Just like mom's!
I didn’t fry in oil - a little butter. Delish. Only trick is getting water out of potatos..
I did half zucchini and half potato. I doubled the recipe to have left overs which were great for lunches.
Absolutely great and easy to make!

I liked this recipe. To avoid oxidation of the potatoes, I put a bowl with salt and water under the shredder. After all the potatoes were shredded, I drained them: Result - no oxidation. 

I will make them again

Omg this are awesome potato pancakes. They remind me of the ones my oma made. They are so simple that I was able to make it for a side dish for my dinner tonight.

Thanks for Sharing!
This was a good basic recipe for German potato pancakes. They came out very tasty. I added more seasonings and used frozen shredded potatoes, which I defrosted in the microwave.

Lot of work for something so utterly bland.
These that are essentially just deep fried hash browns.... in stringy form
Wait until you are ready to cook them immediately before you are ready to cook. I made them about an hour before I needed to cook them and the potatoes turned black. (Oxidation)
I loved these, I added garlic power and my first batch I made with Pam.. they didn’t cook up so well more burned than my second batch which I i used olive oil and they where more moist and crispy.
Nice versatile recipe. I added some turkey bacon, but I still will probably add more salt.
Easy recipe taste great easy to make
Yummy, yummy, yummy!!! The only thing I changed was I doubled the recipe!!!

A little bland, despite adding crumbled bacon and cooking in bacon grease. I meant to do like other reviewers and add garlic powder, but forgot, so mostly made the recipe as written. Shredded the potatoes in the food processor. Pretty quick to assemble, and they held together well in the pan. They did need more than 3 minutes per side to brown. It's hard to go wrong with potatoes in our family, so everyone ate them, but all agreed that they needed a bit more oomph!

I followed the recipe. I used gluten free all purpose flour as my daughter has gluten issues. I did add a sprinkle of garlic powder and some onion powder and parsley flakes. I did squeeze out the excess water from the grated potatoes and ended up adding an additional tablespoon of flour. I fried them in batches of four in a skillet and they turned out quite well. I must say that I feel you should add additional salt upon plating as that does seem to brighten the flavors.

My German grandmother would fry them in a cast iron skillet very thin to where they looked lacy along the fried edge! Maybe used a little less onion though and don’t remember the baking powder! 
Also she grated the potatoes on the smallest grate! Have to press out the water with a spoon!
This is not a German recipe. We do not use flour in kartoffelpfannkuchen but matzoh meal or bread crumbs. Close though.

I've made this twice now. It's better than Perkins pancakes.
Make sure to incorporate the egg juice into each pancake as you place it in to fry. 4 potatoes large size was enough. The best one yet!
I love the recipe, believe it or not topping them with peanut butter is really tasty, also sour cream, we enjoy with any king of sausage and apple sauce.
They tasted very good, the only thing I wasn't fond of was how oily they were but , I will try to make them again.
Easy and fast to prepare. Taste wise is ok.
